contentItem.text: The giant Pacific octopus has lots of powers packed into one creature. Jet propulsion, arm regeneration, instant color-changing camouflage and an ink defense are just a few of them! With a 30 foot wide (9 meters), 600 pound (272 kilograms) body, this creature is one powerhouse of a mollusk!

mediaItem.uri: /wildkratts/media/creaturepedia/21/3-photo or still frame of a Giant Pacific Octopus.png

contentItem.text: The giant Pacific octopus has a beak similar to a parrot's. This beak helps break things open, letting it get to the tasty meat inside. It can also use its strong arms to pry open shells and has the ability to subdue its prey by injecting toxic saliva from its mouth area.

mediaItem.uri: /wildkratts/media/creaturepedia/21/9-video clip of an octopus opening a jar.f4v
/wildkratts/media/creaturepedia/21/3-photo or still frame of a Giant Pacific Octopus.png

contentItem.text: The giant Pacific octopus is a cold water creature and can be found in the Pacific and Atlantic Oceans, further north than almost all other species of octopus.

Giant Pacific octopuses have a few tricks to escape their predators, like harbor seals, sperm whales, sharks, and otters. They hide out in caves, den sites, or within vegetation and use their color-changing camouflage to blend into their surroundings.

mediaItem.uri: /wildkratts/media/creaturepedia/21/8-Enemy asset-Live action footage of octopus on cave like rocks and color change.f4v

contentItem.text: Giant pacific octopuses are considered the most intelligent of all invertebrates (creatures without a backbone). They like to live stylishly as well. Some octopus species will collect crustacean shells and other objects to construct fortresses or "gardens" around their lairs.
